page.title: 05Humphrey Walwyn-Elms School
page.content: Brockbury Hall, now a prosperous dairy farm, was once owned by Humphrey Walwyn. He became a member of the Worshipful Company of Grocers, and in his will of 1612 he entrusted the Company to carry out a generous bequest. This involved the building in 1622 of a Free School in Colwall; later split into The Elms - a fee paying Prep School - and a public Elementary School. The Elms, still in existence, is the oldest Prep School in the country. Inside the school, remains of the 17th century school are still to be seen, as well as a number of cannonballs fired in the Civil War. Today the charitable aims of Humphrey are continued by The Walwyn Foundation, which funds students and apprentices with books and tools. It has also funded the library. The old Elementary School was sold recently.
